quoteFirst: , though he had known it three-quarters of an hour later. He thought it arrived, on the evening in question, at
quoteLast: ; but could not say certainly that the 8th of January was the night when the mail arrived at that time, though he had no doubt of it, nor had he looked at his register since that night. In short, his evidence amounted to a rough guess, which could make no impression on the Gibraltar of opposing testimony furnished by a coach full of passengers, as well as other witnesses.
title:
Ten Years Among the Mail Bags
Or, Notes from the Diary of a Special Agent of the Post-Office Department
author: Holbrook, James, 1812-1864

quoteFirst: A.M.! When we got to station at
quoteLast: she had went! No train to Ballard till night! I and subs, had to wire Bannister for money to get back on! You mis-manager--the _head-work_ you boasted of is boneheadwork! Pay the charges on this, you brainless insect! I'll send it to Butch, for you'd never show it to him if I sent it to you! Indignantly--
title: T. Haviland Hicks, Senior
author: Elderdice, James Raymond, 1889-

quoteFirst: In spite of his resolute assumption of composure, he was getting anxious for the agent’s arrival. The candles had long since been extinguished, and the sunlight of the new morning poured into the room. It was not till
quoteLast: that the gate bell rang, and the agent made his appearance. He was a foreigner with a dark beard.
title: The Woman in White
author: Collins, Wilkie, 1824-1889

quoteFirst: The landlord breathed again. Having seen the end of that matter, he looked at the clock. It was now
quoteLast: . Say one hour more, if all went well. One short hour, and the agony of his suspense would be at an end.
title: Patricia at the inn
author: Snaith, J. C. (John Collis), 1876-1936; Ferguson, W. B. M. (William Blair Morton), 1882-1967 [Author of introduction, etc.]; Matthews, Harry B. [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Only a few shock troops and volunteers of the Volga Regiment, with a company of officers, succeeded in capturing the first line, but the fire was so strong that they failed to keep the position, and towards the afternoon units of the 29th Division returned to their original lines after suffering heavy losses, especially in officers. On the sector of the 51st Division the attack began at
quoteLast: . The 202nd Gori Regiment and the 204th Ardagan-Michailovsky Regiment, as well as two companies of the Sukhum Regiment, with a shock company of the Poti Regiment, made a dash across two lines of trenches, bayoneted the enemy, and began to storm the third line at half-past seven.
title: The Russian Turmoil; Memoirs: Military, Social, and Political
author: Denikin, Anton Ivanovich, 1872-1947

quoteFirst: There could only be the one answer. Mr. Lionel Callon might twist and turn as he pleased, he would spend two years in Chili. It was
quoteLast: , besides. Callon could hardly call at the house in Berkeley Square with any chance of seeing Lady Stretton between now and eight.
title: The Truants
author: Mason, A. E. W. (Alfred Edward Woodley), 1865-1948

quoteFirst: Brigade "X" of the Scottish division was to execute an enveloping movement to the north around Loos and to carry Hill 70 by storm. Brigade "Y" meanwhile was to attack the Loos front, Brigade "Z" remaining in reserve. By

quoteFirst: Tippy would have helped next morning, but she had to bring Belle's children up to spend the day. Aunt Elspeth was very much worse. I took the downstairs guest chamber for my workshop. By
quoteLast: the tulle was spread out on the big four poster, and my scissors were slashing into it. From then on until noon I worked in nightmarish haste. Of course I couldn't have finished it if it had been satin goods or something like that, but the tulle was easy to handle, and I pinned and patted it into shape on patient Sallie Jane till it began to look like the picture I had in mind.
title: Georgina's Service Stars
author: Johnston, Annie F. (Annie Fellows), 1863-1931; Gooch, Thelma, 1895-1973 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Tony tried to be on hand at the time appointed, but he had more than usual to do, and it was
quoteLast: when he entered the field, accompanied by James.
title: Tony, the Hero; Or, A Brave Boy's Adventures with a Tramp

title: A Century of Sail and Steam on the Niagara River

quoteFirst: "I had to pass by Perry's little house. His Mariana was standing at the gate. We got there at
quoteLast: . She had on a blue wrapper, and her hair was pulled back smooth like little girls do when they want to look grown-folksy. She didn't see us till we got close, for she was gazing up the other way.
title: Roads of Destiny
author: Henry, O., 1862-1910

quoteFirst: A series of buzzings, tappings and clinkings came over the wire, with hints of far-distant unintelligible conversation.  This continued while with agonised eyes Esther watched the hands of the big clock on the wall creep from
quoteLast: to eleven past.  Still no connection.  At last the operator, remote and chill as the top of the Tour Eiffel, informed her that there was no reply.
title: Juggernaut
author: Campbell, Alice, 1887-1976

quoteFirst: "Ordered to give you this," he said, "if you made connections. If you'd been later than
quoteLast: , I was to keep dark. You've got seven minutes and a half to spare. Queer orders, but the big railroad boss, Woodbridge, give 'em to me.
title: A Court of Inquiry
author: Richmond, Grace S. (Grace Smith), 1866-1959
